snippet: Students could be found in contingency programs at schools, in churches and in day care centers. Some slept late, stayed home alone and wandered neighborhoods.
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of families' lives in Chicago are turned upside down as the ongoing strike of public schoolteachers, which has stretched for three days, drags on; students can be found in contingency programs, costly day care centers, or wandering their neighborhoods as if it is still summer; many parents have expressed patience and even support for the strike, but tolerance is waning as the city's first school strike in 25 years shows no signs of ending.

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and STEVEN YACCINO

lead_paragraph: Students could be found in contingency programs at schools, in churches and in day care centers. Some slept late, stayed home alone and wandered neighborhoods.

headline.main: As Chicago Teachers Strike, Students Are on the Loose and at Loose Ends
headline.print_headline: In Chicago, on the Loose And at Loose Ends
